review_text: I was on the hunt for the best headphones for my hearing aid mic pack because I have to wear them for long periods of time and the headphones I had were uncomfortable. These are… also uncomfortable. They are quite tight to the ear and small so they push on the shell of the ear which is what I was trying to avoid from the last pair. Upside was that the sound was pretty good, but yeah, not for me. I gave them to my mom as she likes this style because it doesn’t fully cover the ear and she can use them while playing video games. They were cheap so I’m not torn up about it, but yeah, not for me. Also didn’t love the right angle jack because it takes up too much space on my hearing aid as the jack is in between the volume nob and the mic and it made the cord stick out in a weird way so it would not be easy to adjust the volume which is necessary for me.

review_text: These phones are an excellent quality. I compared them to me Bose wireless and they compared very well when listening to lively organ music, in particular "Emperor's Fanfare" by Soler, played on the church organ in Santanyi Spain by Paul Fey. That combo is my gold standard for audio evaluations. The Bose had better bass response, of course, but these earphones didn't leave you wishing you had upgraded. A very good headphone unless you are an audio professional, which I am decidedly not.  I have no reservations about this purchase. Go for it.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Best value and comfort for Web meetings
review_text: As someone who spends throughout the day in Web meetings, a comfortable and long lasting headphone is a must.  I've tried many, including earbuds and have come to appreciate this one. What I like:- Comfort:  When you sometimes spends hours in Web meetings, on-ear headphones becomes really painful.  Over-the-ear also shuts out outside sounds better than on-ear.- Wired: I don't have to worry about running out of charge like earbuds and wireless headphones.  The sound quality is also guaranteed to be consistent over wireless.- Inexpensive:  At this price-point, I can easily buy another one if it gets broken (usually from me stepping on them).- Sound quality: The meeting participants couldn't really differentiate the sound quality with likes of Bose.  NOTE: The results may be different when using for other than Web meetings where sound quality is critical.- 3.5mm Jack:  This is the gold standard for sound.  I've had USB-based headphones and had issues with the USB-driver. Fortunately, all 4 laptops I own (3 Lenovo Windows & Macbook Air M2) have 3.5mm port.- Brand:  Panasonic is not a fly-by-night and they're known to product quality products.

They sound the exact same too, which is to say surprisingly good. Mids and highs are clear, bass isn’t muddled and has good thump to it. They’re super light and comfortable. All around solid headphones and huge bang for your buck.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Sounds amazing! But jack is too thick with phone case without modifying!
review_text: The sound from this RP-HT21M blows my mind! I did not know these videos I'm watching have bass like this in them also high frequency clarity is crisp. Two things surprised me though. First is the 90 degree connection! May end up liking it but I expected a straight jack. Second! The jack will NOT fit your phone with a case on it! Too thick to be able to plug it in! Took a razor blade and cut a ring about 2mm off the black rubber around the jack and then grinded it carefully with a rotary tool for good measure to reduce the diameter to fit the hole in my phone case. ( as others show in reviews doing similar fix )I like the slim design you can lean back in bed against the pillow and it is not pushing on the headphones! Have not tried the microphone yet but I'm sure it will be ok! Again! Sounds amazing!!! Plugged in my old larger over the ear headphones for comparison right after listening with this one , the old one sounded like a telephone dropped in the bottom of a bucket! This thing is fantastic!

Where I can change bass, tremble and whatever to my hearts desire and can switch between 1 or 2 of those or back to factory setting.  Also love the long batt life and comfort of wearing.  Really great quality for the price. Orginally I tried to find a cheaper  under $100 but good quality sounding product and came across cowin and got the E7. I  spent more then double for those, around $80 and they couldn't do any of that. Also they were nothing like advertised. The set I got was this ugly mismatched color of aqua blue and green . Which was nothing like the emerald green / solid one color I would get.  When I asked to return, they made me pay an add $11 return shipping and tracking, even though the product was nothing like advertised. Then tried to scam me out of my money by ghosting me after they recieved the return. Ended up having to contact bank and file a report after no response from them after 2 months of no response or reimbursement. Ended up finding these afterwards and I do not regret buying these.  I love them and the color which is my fave color. The price for quality is great.  I cant wait to also use these at the gym . I would def highly suggest these. Sony is a well known brand  with known quality products. Don't go thru the rabbit hole like I did try these out worse case you return or keep as a backup for gym. I personally wanted a set i wouldnt be too upset if they broke while using at the gym. This is that set and im in love. Plus AMAZON  is great when it comes to customer service. So give them a try.

review_title:
2.0 out of 5 stars
Great Sound but with some issues
review_text: These Sony headphones sound incredible, and they fit snug for immersive listening. However, that's where the positives end for me.The user experience is hampered by several design choices. The small power button is fiddly and difficult to locate by touch. The Bluetooth pairing function is integrated with the power button, meaning that holding it for slightly too long to initiate pairing can accidentally power the headphones off entirely, which is quite frustrating. Charging is also a step backward in modern convenience. While the headphones do feature a USB-C charging port, Sony bafflingly included a low-voltage, slow-charging USB-A to USB-C cable, instead of a modern USB-C to USB-C cable that would allow for faster charging and utilize current power bricks. They included a short, 6-inch cable which would not allow enough reach to charge while listening and multitasking on the phone.Crucially, these headphones have significant compatibility issues, even after extensive troubleshooting (I've tried all possible resets and re-pairings). While they work fine for basic audio playback from my Android phone, they consistently fail to connect to other devices like my iPad or TV, severely limiting their versatility. Most importantly for my needs, they are not compatible with my DJI Mic receiver for live audio monitoring during recording; they only work for audio playback after a recording is complete. This makes them unusable for my workflow.Despite their genuinely great sound, I cannot recommend these headphones if you need multi-device functionality, live audio monitoring capabilities, or expect the fast charging and modern conveniences that come with USB-C. They are simply too limited for anything beyond basic audio playback on a single device.

review_text: I bought these because they’re Sony and they’re cheap. I was immediately impressed with the quality materials used, not cheap brittle plastic and really good cables. They fit my huge head pretty well and I really like the cups rotating flat for storage. I might buy another pair for backup though I think these will be plenty durable. The sound quality is freaking impressive at all audio levels! Nice and clear. I’m hearing elements in my old music that I never noticed before, tracks mixed in that were too muddy for my ears to pick out before. Even though these things probably shouldn’t be able to knock out the lower bass tones, it does very well though if I really push it at higher volume for an extended period, the bass will start to crackle a little bit. It could be my cheap Pyle amp. It’s not really supposed to drive 24 ohm headphones.  Anyway, way to go Sony!

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Good Sounding Headphones Limited by Their On-Ear Form factor
review_text: Pros:* Comfortable* Well built* Battery length estimate from mfgr is accurate* Excellent app* Sound quality is well balanced, no dominant EQ range over any other* Controls are well placed and reliably functioning.CONS:* On ear headphones do not provide optimal noise cancellation. These are certainly better than nothing, but nowhere near as good as headphones with over ear cushions, like Jlabs own JLabs Lux (without the "GO" designation).* On ear headphones also do not seal the sound is as well as over ears, so if you like really deep bass, you are not going to find it here.* The headphone frame is a bit small, for my large hat sized head. I need to ratchet the arms out to maximum extension and even then, the fit is not optimal.Bottom Line:Some people don't like headphone cushions that cover the entire ear, due to the perception that such designs are hot and / or uncomfortable. If you are one of those folks - and you have a small or medium sized head - these are an excellent choice. The sound is well tuned, the app is really useful, the NC is adequate for medium demand use (subway OK, plane less so), and the headphones were built with excellent quality control. I would especially praise JLAB for not smothering the sound profile with sludgy inaccurate bass, a common failure with inexpensive / small brand headphones. These were tuned by someone that knows accurate sound and cares about providing such to a customer.If you want better sound, better NC, and have a bigger head (and don't mind over ear designs) you should spend a few dollars more and get the "non-GO" version of the JLab Lux, their over ear fitting model.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Comfortable Noise Cancelling Bluetooth Headphones
review_text: Pairing this with my child’s MP3 player was seamless and very easy. She was giggling with how quickly we got that part figured out. The sound is extremely clear and not muffled. They definitely have the noise-cancelling feature that makes listening in a busy household so much more enjoyable. She really likes the texture and feeling of the ear pads– it is a soft foam with a kind of fabric over the top that is similar to a silky faux leather. I tried them on and agreed they are incredibly comfy on the ears. I wear glasses so that is a big deal with headphones pushing against my ears. The top of the headphones does sit kind of heavy on the top of my head, however. That might just be because I have a big head? It doesn’t bother my daughter at all.  But the ear comfort is fantastic for both of us. The headphones also don’t leak sound like some others we have– so when my daughter is jamming out, I don’t have to hear it!

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Not the best for working out, but sound good
review_text: -Look great.  Very minimal and sleek. Matte mauve color is unique and stylish.-Comfy and pretty lightweight as far as over ear headphones go.  I am used to using in-ear headphones, so the over the ear versions are inherently heavier. I find that I can only wear these for a few hours before needing a break, but don't know that that would be different for any over ear versions. These have great padding on the ears.  I have a very big head so they have to stretch a bit, but fit well. I do find that they get a bit hot if using for a long time.-Sound good. Good base.  You lose a little something on the high notes/upper registers.  They can sound a bit tinny, not as round, but not bad, and that seems to be the case for all but the most expensive earphones. Overall I think they sound great.-The noise canceling feature works pretty well. You can still hear the world around you but it is muffled. I do find that I feel like I am in a tunnel with them on.  Feel like I can hear my own heartbeat in my head.  So took a little getting used to. Again, I don't like to use them like this for more than a few hours at a time.-Not my favorite for working out.  They tend to slip down into your face if you bend forward.  So I find that I am constantly readjusting them if I wear them while doing something very active.  Maybe this is just a fit issue for me? Not sure. These are best suited to seated work, light walking, or housework.

review_text: These really are decent headphones for their price point of $49.99. They don't have the crisp bass response of a $250.00 pair, nor do they have the volume headroom (they don't get as loud) that more expensive pairs have but they are full featured with voice prompts that tell you when settings change and the battery level.They're decently comfortable with flat-faced ear cushions as compared to expensive headphones that have a built-in air space between your ear and the cushion.Well worth their price.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Excellent default sound signature. Comfortable on ear headband. Every feature I can think of.
review_text: JLab is a well-known brand for making excellent products. The Go Lux Headband is another one of those excellent products. I am not a fan of the ear covering headbands (I refer to them as earmuff headsets) unless needed for extreme noise cancelling. The go Lux headband does not completely cover the ear but rests upon it with a soft rubber-like, foam filled covering. These are very comfortable without contributing to the "ear-claustrophobia" (my made-up word) syndrome. My most used headsets are over-ear air conduction types. When I want to listen to Bass-forward music I'll use in-ear earbuds, and for sports, pool or workouts it's bone conduction. I wanted to try the Go Lux since it has almost every feature that can be offered on a headset and thought it would be comfortable as a sometime replacement for in-ear earbuds - and it is. The default sound signature is great but when in the mood for more Bass the app has a Bass boost pre-select option. For those who need even more Bass, the custom equalizer can do that. ANC works but is only moderately effective based on my testing. Still nice to have it. Spatial sound expands the sound stage. I keep Spatial sound on all the time. The Go Lux can get dangerously loud. The Safe Hearing feature is a must-have with this kind of volume capability. Playtime is rated at 70+ hours. After going through a lengthy period of heavy testing, I fully charged it and left it in the box unused for several weeks. I put them on to write this review and they connected immediately to my phone showing 100% power. Multi-point connections worked as expected. Call quality is very good for both parties. I reported on some of the most important features to me. I'll leave reading the complete list of features to the official product description. Considering the comfort, construction, sound quality and feature set, this is a good value 5-star headset.

review_text: These headphones sound pretty good and the 3 modes of noise cancellation can make a big difference.  You can choose to cancel ambient noise, or in the "be-aware" mode actually amplify it.  The ear cushions are soft and comfortable, but are made from a non-breathable material which becomes less comfortable after being worn for a while.  The headband can be adjusted, but in its tightest setting still leaves the headphones somewhat loose such that they can slip down or fall off with running, biking, or other exercise. If you're just sitting down they fit good.  The current Amazon listing price of $50 represents a reasonable value for this item.

review_title:
3.0 out of 5 stars
Noise reduction, not noise canceling
review_text: The JLab Go Lux ANC Wireless Headphones are supposed to be noise canceling, but that is incorrect. It would be more correct to say noise reduction. I like the padding, but it does get warm after some time. Due to the way my ears are shaped, headphones work better for me than earbuds. I do wear glasses, so finding headphones that are comfortable with extended wear is hard to come by. These headphones are no exception. Maybe they are just too small for my head, but I don't think so. I have used these on a call, and it was a bit of a pain to get them working correctly. Once I did, the call went fine. I do think these are overpriced because the main features for me, noise canceling & comfort, are not the greatest.

review_title:
3.0 out of 5 stars
Good, but overpriced 🎧
review_text: I test headphones so you don't have too!🎧 I test tons of personal audio equipment. I put everything I review through the same tests for consistency. I use a Dolby EQ app and my phone because that's how I listen to my  music.Alot of what comes my way for review aren't familiar brands, but I know the name Jlab, and their gear tends to be hit or miss.  They're good, but not great. They are comfortable and seem well built and the button configuration is pretty standard so they're easy to use. The battery life is decent. The connectivity rage is ok. The volume range is just right, so you have room to crank them up a bit for that jam but he bass is lacking. The sound is and balanced, but maybe too balanced so the bass comes off a little weak. The ANC is decent for on ear phones. At this price point I've reviewed lots of lesser known on ear headphones that deliver better bass  a better connection range. So in the end for me, these are good, but not great. And honestly, they are a bit overpriced given what they lack.

The headphones by default are lacking in base, but perform well at midrange to tenor points. The Active noise cancelling is suprisingly impressive for being on-ear headphones. However, the ear cups are completely flat, which results in some difficulty when it comes to staying on your head. The material seems durable, but also hard to replace if broken. The software for android works incredibly seamlessly, and I'm satisfied. The color is difficult to pair with outfits, as the green is a very odd color. Its battery life is mid-range at best, though can be used for up to a week without recharge regardless.

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Smooth Sound; Surprisingly Comfortable Fit; ANC Sort Of
review_text: I’ve had these for a bit over a month now, to be sure I would not rely on first impressions.On-Ear vs. Over Ear—Everyone DiffersI use headphones for periods up to three hours at a time, sometimes four.  Inevitably I have felt a degree of discomfort on the ears when I’ve used on-ear headphones.  This discomfort never has been present with over the ear style.  I confess I got these knowing my previous experiences, but I was willing to try again, knowing JBL’s reputation for sound, the fact that ANC is touted for these, and the fact that I am entirely satisfied with a pair of JBL earbuds I do have that do not have ANC.The cushioning for these is very very good, and the on ear pressure from the headband is not bad at all.The sound is surprisingly good, and one can tailor the sound using an equalizer if one wishes.  Bass seemed to get somewhat better over time.  Perhaps that needed a break-in period.  Bass is smooth and certainly is not boomy.  Overall, though 25% of my earphone usage is musical, I’d say JBL did a good job on these headphones, considering the price.Push button control is good.  Sound feed thru for the pass sound through mode is satisfactory though not using that mode is also satisfactory.  However, I did find the ANC to be unimpressive, likely in part because these are, after all, on-ear headphones, which invite sound pass through, either way, by their very nature.  (I have a pair of $40 ear buds with ANC that is so good that I use them on airplanes.)Do I still prefer over-ear headphones?  Absolutely, but they can get warm over time; I can count on these to allow better air circulation when it is needed.  Rotation between types may be in order.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Fantastic customizability
review_text: -- Active Noise Cancellation --The ANC works well, but likely would be better with over-ear instead of on-ear cups. With that said, it does perform better than I expected. The intensity is customizable in the app; a fantastic feature especially for sensitive ears. Low ANC blocks some bass noise, while high ANC blocks a significant amount of bass noise, less mids, and minimal highs.-- Passive Noise Cancellation --PNC does not block a lot of sound, which I attribute to the on-ear form factor. The pads are comfortable, but I found that the tips of my ears started to hurt after a little bit.-- Fit and Comfort --As said above, the ear pads are pretty comfortable, but I had minor pain in my ears after a while. This may get better with time. Because these are on-ear, there isn't much holding them in place; I found that they were vulnerable to jostling. Not great for walking around during a commute, and I would be worried about them falling off if I were running to catch a bus. The build does feel nice and solid, though, so I wouldn't be too worried about wear and tear.-- Sound Quality --The sound quality is excellent, with booming bass and defined highs. You can customize the equalizer in the app to suit your taste.-- App --These are the most customizable headphones I've ever owned, and I love it. The ANC/PNC/Awareness cycle can be adjusted, if you wanted to remove awareness mode or ANC from the rotation when pressing the ANC button, for example. There is a good slider-based equalizer with three presets: JLab Signature, Balanced, Bass Boost. I prefer JLab Signature, which is the default. Like the ANC button, the other buttons' controls are customizable. You can set one, two, and three tap actions, and long presses of the volume buttons, and they can be set to switch EQ, last track, next track, volume up/down, noise control, google/siri. There is an option for spatial audio, which creates a cool directional audio effect. There is also a safe hearing mode, but it seems to be a straight volume decrease, not a limiter.

Despite their subpar customer service on other products, I thought the lower price would be a good palliative measure to ease any disappointment.No disappointment here, though. Loud enough to cause ringing ears (but please don't go that far) and clear enough you can make out all the tiny nuances and even some of the more obscured instruments in your music. Just what I needed, so for once, Sony got it 95% right rather than their usual 60%. The one thing I don't like is the short cord. I have to plug it in at the front of my PC rather than to the sound card. A short extension solves that problem, but still, I'd have preferred to have another 18 inches or so on the cord.But hey, I have my music, which is all I wanted. I'm good.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Long lasting functionality
review_text: NOTE: The attached pictures are of my (six year old) pair.I bought an identical pair (same brand, color, etc) a few years back when I graduated high school. I really liked them and they are an affordable price, so I bought this pair for my sister.My pair has worked well all these years and still provides excellent sound quality. It has been almost six years and they are just now starting to wear. The ear cushions are tearing off and a tiny bit of the paint is beginning to chip - and this is after almost daily use for five and a half years and carrying them around in my backpack half the time. I personally don't mind the tearing as they still hold together well enough and I don't notice the tearing when wearing the headphones - the cushion itself is still good. The mic still works great and so does the sound functionality. I imagine they will last many more years to come.These headphones are adjustable and the ears are even labeled: "R" for "Right ear"; "L" for "Left ear".

After a while it began to hurt and made my ear sweat a little. I knew it was coming, it's like that with all these on-the-ear sets.. I mean that's why they call them "ON the ear", right? So, I'm not complaining really, just saying that's what I didn't like about them. I don't regret the purchase. They were exactly what I needed them to be and now they're serving another purpose so, money well spent.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Surprisingly good travel headphones for the price.
review_text: This is a Boomer review since younger people know much more about headphones than I do, and everyone has them.  But for those who only use headphones on the plane, especially for the noise canceling feature, this is for you.  I specifically looked for plug-in headphones because they are more comfortable than earbuds, and more reliable than bluetooth.  No, these are not Bose headphones, but hilariously, they rank second to Bose on many reviewers' lists!I bought these to replace my 15 year old Audio Technica headphones that still work but are falling apart.  I took both pairs with me on a recent trip and did a comparison.  I could not tell a difference between them, even though the Audio Technica ones covered my ears better.  When not watching movies I wore them just for the noise-cancelling feature, which worked just fine.  I am a relatively small woman so larger people might have a different experience with ear coverage.  These earphones fold up and become quite compact so they don't take up much room in your carry-on bag.  They fit neatly into small, semi-circular cases that are readily available on Amazon, and which  I highly recommend.  The nearly identical version of these headphones at about half the price does not have the noise canceling feature.  Make sure you get the ones with a product number that ends in NC.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
takes some abuse
review_text: I have gone thru a couple of pairs of these over the years, and the reason I replace them is that I did something to damage them. So lets be realistic about what you are getting. You are getting a pair of portable headphones that will REDUCE any surrounding noise to the point that whatever you are trying to listen to can be heard. They are not going to silence the surrounding noise, no open element headphone can. These are not the headphones I use when I am flying a plane, but they are the ones I use when I am flying commercially on a A320 and watching movies or listening to music. The battery life is very good, they fold up to reduce the amount of space they take up in your carry on, and they have a nice long cord . IMHO great bang for the buck.

review_title:
1.0 out of 5 stars
Not Noise Cancelling -- Only amplifies incoming signal
review_text: This product does not actively cancel noise. Unlike normal noise cancelling headphones, there is no discernible decrease in ambient noise when switched "on" without a music source. I tested the product using my loud kitchen fan (and yes, I installed the batteries). Instead of cancelling noise, the "on" button appears to amplify the incoming signal, like a "loud" button on an old stereo. Avoid this product if you are looking for noise cancelling headphones.

review_title:
2.0 out of 5 stars
Basically false advertising.
review_text: My sister got these for me for Christmas, knowing that i was looking for noise cancelling headphones so I wasn’t destroying my hearing. A big part of noise canceling headphones is that you don’t need to turn music up loud to hear since all outside noise is tuned out. Sony said on the box that it removes 95% of noise. That’s not true at all. I have to turn them up just as loud as my $10 wireless earbuds. The sound quality is okay but it removes maybe about 50% of ambient noise. Also, the sound quality is only good when turned up. These get quite dull and somewhat muddy at low volume which again makes them basically useless as advertised. They’re just cheap over ear headphones. That’s it. I’d be fine with them if they weren’t trying to claim 95% noise cancellation. Find something else. You also have to use a battery which is fun, I love listening to music only for the battery to die halfway through. They’re not rechargeable batteries either, it’s a physical battery. That’s just annoying in this day and age. I don’t want to spend a ton of money on batteries, we know they aren’t cheap anymore, and it makes so much additional waste. Buy something else.

They may not last forever and don't have remarkable sound quality, but if you are need a pinch and need something functional and comfortable for everyday use, these will get the job done for music, YouTube, etc.  I had no issues using these on my flight and fortunately are foldable so that they are easy to travel with. review_text: Bought these for a trip and was excited to try them out on the plane.  They actually did a really good job with canceling out the noise of the plane!  They're wired so you an use them without batteries if your batteries every run out (but it won't sound so good).  Even found the perfect case to go with these on Amazon that was so cheap. The only thing I struggled with was that they started to hurt my ears (since they're not over the ear headphones) and the top of my head (no padding) after about 2 hours.  I've tried using them at Starbucks when working and same thing happens.  These are great for short-time use. I used them at the gym for 40-ish minutes and they were great!  But might be uncomfortable for you for long-term use.  The price is great though!

Save $20 and get the ZX110 or find a different headphone that really has noise-cancelling.

review_title:
1.0 out of 5 stars
Huge Drop In Quality- Don‘t Buy
review_text: I first started buying these headphones a year or two ago when the first pair broke after a year of use. Not a big deal and they were only 30 dollars and lasted so long, so I bought another pair.  That had a sharp drop in quality and rise in price, resulting in them breaking in about 4 months. For some foolish reason, I bought another pair for now $50. These ones barely lasted two weeks before snapping. I‘m not rough with my headphones, I don’t take them on rocket ships or beat them with hammers- they stay on my head or by my desk and somehow manage to snap themselves as i leaned against the wall. Seriously, how do headphones snap from leaning gently against a wall? I‘m a little teenage girl, not a body builder or the type to slam my head against walls. You’re better off buying anything else, all these other good reviews are outdated.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
At this price point, these are unmatched!! GREAT BATTERY LIFE!!
review_text: I've purchased MANY sets of Bluetooth headphones at many different price points. For the price, these are THE BEST!! Battery life is unmatched. I use them daily and may have to charge them once a week, if that!! Great sound and connect seamlessly to my phone. I've used other name brand headphones that cost A WHOLE LOT MORE than these, and for this price, the quality is unmatched! I can hear both music and phone calls wonderfully and I've never had any complaints from people on the other end not being able to hear me, so the microphone works great, too.

But even without custom settings, you simply can't beat these for 20 bucks. Especially if you like to hear the full spectrum of bass, straight down to 20hz. These can go very loud as well.Fit/Comfort - 8/10Depending on how you set them on your ears can impact the perceieved sound, this is just a general disadvantage of on ear headphones. These clamp down comfortably and do a great job blocking out backround noise passively. They're pretty lightweight so easy to walk around with. Might be a bit too loose for more intense workouts, though.Build quality - 10/10At 20 bucks these are very nice. Lightweight but sturdy build. They fold up nicely for travel or storage as well.Features/functions - 10/10App with a 9 band customizable EQ,Multipoint pairing,Wireless and wired input options (Aux cable included),Folds up nicely,Seemingly endless battery life,All for 20 bucks!? YES PLEASE!!!

review_title:
1.0 out of 5 stars
Two different pairs broke the exact same way.
review_text: UPDATE: Anker very generously offered to send me a new set of these headphones, which I accepted, in hopes that the “third time’s a charm” rule would ring true! I definitely respect Anker for their efforts to make things right by their customers.Unfortunately, eventually the new headphones met the same end, snapping at the same weak spot at the joint between the band and earpiece, despite that I was EXTRA careful with them this time because of my past experiences.Anker puts out some great products—I own several—this just doesn’t happen to be one of them.————-I loved these headphones - great sound quality for the price, comfortable, understated aesthetics; these headphones checked all the right boxes for me. That is, until they broke at the thin joint between the band and the earpiece.I take very good care of my headphones, even the crappy-quality ones I just like for their unique looks. And I definitely took care of these Soundcores. So when they snapped at the joint, I figured maybe I got a flawed set, and didn’t think twice about purchasing a replacement.Sadly, the second pair snapped at the very same joint.Needless to say I won’t be purchasing a third pair, nor can I recommend anyone else do so. They’ll only make you love them, then turn around and break your heart.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Comfortable, quality sound, great bluetooth
review_text: I bought the h10 (holiday sale $22) to use with a 9 band equalizer. I'm not yet willing or ready for hearing aids! I used an optical splitter (BlueRigger Toslink digital optical audio splitter adapter around $8). Connect splitter to TV optical output and one port goes to soundbar and other port to the digital to analog decoder which ill describe  in a minute. I can now hear 2KHz and above thx to the equalizer (behringer mini fbq800 from Sweetwater.com around $70). BTW, I have Bose OVER the ear ANC ($$$$) but wanted simple ON the ears and h10 is perfect ($). My wife likes the sound very low from the soundbar and I can now turn up the headphones volume to add many more years to a happy marriage. As for gear, connect TV optical to OREI DA34 digital to analog decoder audio converter (this unit processes the all-important Dolby signal and PCM) around $30. Connect the DA34 to the equalizer. In order to provide Bluetooth, output the equalizer to a wireless Bluetooth transmitter. I use the MEE audio Connect around $20. Turn on TV, equalizer, put h10 into pairing mode (press button for 5 sec) and press MEE button. Voila. Yes, there is a very slight audio latency with Bluetooth in the headphones, but the soundbar volume is low and the earphones is a bit higher so it is not distracting for me. If the soundbar is off, it's all moot.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Done With Buds Forever, Incredible Value
review_text: I collect headphones, or as some might say, I'm a headphone hobbyist. In my collection are HiFiMan, Sennheiser, and AKG high-end headphones. I always used a set of buds for knocking around, walking the dog, and talking on the phone. My last two pairs were from Soundcore, including Liberty Pro 3s which I paid over $100 for. They were okay, but despite trying many different tips, they would fall out of my ear, not provide a good seal, I'd accidentally hang-up on folks by pushing a bud back into my ear or eventually get clogged with earwax.This time when it came time to replace my buds I thought I'd try something different. Despite my bad experiences with buds, I've always appreciated the value, sound, and features of Soundcore products. Because I have no use for gimmicks like noise-canceling, etc., I looked through the line-up to see which set of Soundcore cans had none of those useless (to me) features and found these for $25-ish.As far as price-to-quality ratio, these are easily the best headphones I've ever owned. The microphone is stellar (it sounds as good as most podcasts I listen to, even better than some), the sound for listening to calls or podcasts is great, and to my surprise, music sounds better than virtually any bud I've ever owned. And even music sounds great, which was not even my main usage for these. Do they have as flat and detailed of a response as my best, open-back headphones...? Of course not. They have a bit of boost in the bass, like many less expensive earphones. However, even this can be adjusted with the EQ in the free SoundCore app.Much to my surprise, given that they don't even cover the entire ear, wearing them even without anything playing seems to block out about 85% of outside noise. I will say, they fit very snugly, some might even say tight. My head must be on the smaller side, because I rarely have to extend headphones beyond the smallest size, and still they are VERY snug. I doesn't bother me, but they might become uncomfortable after an hour or two. However, I don't use these for long listening sessions... I have many, much better wired headphones for that.These are the best Bluetooth headphones I've ever had, including my first pair ever, my now long-gone $300 Sony MDR-1R. For $25! For that money, I was expecting something with good utility for my purposes. What I got was a really fun pair of cans.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Absolutely best fullsize headphones for price to performance
review_text: Anker always comes through with excellent products that hit the sweet spot on price without compromises in features. The H30i has an awesome battery life that's taken me multiple days to totally run through. The microphone quality is great for phone calls and I never have issues with clarity. Audio quality is great, bass is great. The buttons are just what you need and nothing unnecessary yet give a satisfying and responsive click. The H30i's USB-C port is great and let's you get rid of your outdated USB Micro-B cables. The earcups have the ability to swivel and spin together with an adjustable band for improved comfort. The design is professional yet elegant. The H30i even supports a headphone jack. Unfortunately, the H30i's internal microphone does not work while wired, but you can buy an aux cable with an inline microphone to use the H30i as a proper headset even while wired. Absolutely get this if you're looking for full-sized headphones, don't want to break the bank and not concerned about active noise cancellation.

Great Headphones!
review_text: So here's my story my wife and I were on a trip to San Antonio TX and I forgot to pack my Beats Studio headphones for the plane. So we went to Ross in Albuquerque and I found these Anker Souncore H30i headphones for $20 all I can say is WOW! They have great bass clarity and to be honest they are louder than my Beats I paid $200 for on sale. Now the noise cancelling isn't as good as the Beats and the comfort is so so BUT overall for $20 had I knew these were that good I wouldn't have over spent. Moral of story you don't have to spend $200 to get great sound from headphones. I will be buying more Anker Souncore products

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Impressive Wired Headphones for Audio Enthusiasts
review_text: I recently purchased a pair of wired headphones, and I must say, they have completely elevated my audio experience. Here's a detailed review:Sound Quality:The standout feature of these headphones is undeniably the exceptional sound quality. The clarity, depth, and balance across the entire spectrum are remarkable. Whether I'm listening to music, watching movies, or gaming, the headphones deliver a rich and immersive audio experience. The bass is deep without being overpowering, and the highs and mids are crisp and detailed.Comfort:Comfort is crucial for extended listening sessions, and these headphones excel in that department. The ear cushions are plush and provide a snug fit without causing discomfort. The adjustable headband ensures a customized fit for various head sizes. I can wear them for hours without any signs of fatigue or discomfort.Build Quality:The build quality of these headphones is impressive. The materials used feel durable and sturdy, giving the headphones a premium look and feel. The adjustable headband and swiveling ear cups add to the overall flexibility and durability of the design. The detachable cable is a practical feature that adds to the longevity of the headphones.Noise Isolation:The headphones offer excellent noise isolation, effectively blocking out external sounds and allowing me to enjoy my audio without distractions. This is particularly beneficial when using them in noisy environments or during travel.Cable and Connectivity:The wired connection provides a reliable and uninterrupted audio experience. The included cable is of high quality and has a sufficient length, giving me flexibility in my movements while connected to various devices. The universal compatibility ensures that I can use these headphones with a wide range of audio sources.Overall, these wired headphones have exceeded my expectations. They strike an impressive balance between outstanding audio quality, comfort, and durability. If you're an audio enthusiast looking for a reliable pair of wired headphones, I highly recommend considering this option. They deliver a premium listening experience that is well worth the investment.

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Obnoxious Interference
review_text: Usually, I prefer to use wireless ear buds, but I use them for hours a day and was getting frustrated when needing to take them out to charge. As an alternative, I looked at over the ear wired headphones that connected with a c-type USB, but I definitely didn't want to spend more than $30 on a pair since they'd be my in-between while my buds charge, so here we are with the Kensington headphones. Overall, they are very good - sound quality is great, and despite the ear coverage not being a tight seal, enough ambient noise is blocked so that I can enjoy the music, but not so blocked that I can't hear important background noises (doorbell, kids screaming, etc.). They are comfortable on my ears and on my head, which hasn't been my experience in the pas with headphones. That said, there is random and often obnoxious interference that comes through, and I can't pinpoint if maybe it's something with my phone or some kind of external interference from a computer or something like that, but it does seem that no matter where I set my phone, the interference happens. If you've ever used dial-up internet, you will remember the unique tapping that would emit through computer speakers just before the phone rang, and that is not only the type of interference, but has many times been the exact sound I get. All-in-all, even with that interference, these are good headphones.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Plug and Play, no complicated buttons whatsoever, exactly what you need!
review_text: I usually don't write reviews. When I do, it's because a product actually solves my problem.You see, almost all the headset you find on Amazon all comes with a few buttons, and "long press here to turn on" and "push that button to pause/play" that kind of stuff. All that does is to confuse the consumer. I need to buy a headset for a senior family member, I cannot teach them to do "long press" here and "pause/play" there. I need a headset that behaves like an old school headset: just plug it in and it works!This headset does JUST THAT! No buttons, no manual to read, just plug into your phone and it works!If you get frustrated by electronics designed by engineers who don't understand consumers, buy this headset!

I remember my much more expensive headphones from the 1970s, and these are head and shoulders above those, at a fraction of the price. When I want crazy sound, and bass that backs out my fillings, I turn to my Sennheisers; but for working all day at my computer, these couldn't be better. I've grown to dislike earbuds for a number of reasons and I've gone back to cans.What's that...? You're going to make me say something negative? *sigh* Oh alright: they're a little snug and my reading glasses make grooves in my head when I wear these for a few hours. That's on me for not taking breaks like I should. Does that snugness cost these a star? Nope. It helps them stay put.

review_title:
3.0 out of 5 stars
Not suitable for my needs as a constant user.
review_text: I’m a nearly 24/7 headphones wearer so have a lot of important criteria. My current daily drivers are the skullcandy uproar wireless, which have been frustratingly discontinued, so… the search begins. First and foremost, my headphones need to be comfortable and they can not make me overheat. These were both a little uncomfortable, and already made me feel too warm within just a few minutes of wear. I specifically gave these a chance because another reviewer said they didn’t cause overheating, but this was not the case for me. A lot of the discomfort was from the tightness of the band, which will loosen over time so I’m willing to forgive it, but the ear cups—while decently soft and squishy—seemed to reflect my own body heat back at me and amplify it. This would make them unwearable for even an hour, let alone a full day. I will say that I appreciated the design of how the band is adjusted, because they adjust higher up, meaning it gives both a little more width and a little more length than other, similar designs. Many headphones continue to squeeze your ears tight to the side of your face no matter how long the extension is, but the additional widening helped enough that I can see how they’d be very comfortable with some wearing in.These sound excellent, which I’ve come to expect from Skullcandy. The sound is clear and un-muffled, and does not feel lacking. I don’t really know the differences in sound descriptions and words, but skullcandy has always sounded very, very good to me when it comes to listening to every kind of media I can think of.The buttons are too small to quickly find when you need to pause or adjust the volume, and I pause my sound a significantly high number of times per day, so this would be a problem. I could add dots of puffy paint to them if I wanted to make them more prominent, but I’d already decided these weren’t keepers. They’re also grouped really closely together and feel sort of “mushy” when you press them, which makes the physical act of doing so a bit difficult if your fingertips are hyperflexible. The absolute distaste I have for these buttons was a HUGE part of rejecting the headphones overall, as well as the fact there seems to be a bit of a delay when you press play/pause to when it actually activates. So on top of pressing the button being a slow event, the action itself is slowed, as well. No thanks.All in all, these are not the WORST headphones I’ve ever tried, but I decided in less than an hour they weren’t worth a hoot at all for me.If you’re also a nonstop headphones user, I’d recommend finding something else for your daily driver.

4.0 out of 5 stars
Good bass response, excellent volume.  USB-C connection required.
review_text: These headphones sound pretty good.  The bass is nice, and while they don't have active noise-canceling, they do a good job of insulating your ear from outside noise.  The volume is excellent; I don't listen anywhere close to full volume as that gets pretty loud.  Note that these headphones have a USB-C connection; they don't use older 3.5mm or quarter-inch headphone jacks so make sure your source device supports USB-C headphones.  I used an adapter to plug these headphones into a USB-A port, and while it worked for the most part, I don't think the connection was quite stable enough to use on a regular basis and I wouldn't recommend going that route.

Earbuds tend to hurt my ears after wearing them for a while, so these headphones are a great alternative. The sound quality is impressive for the price. The USB-C connection is super convenient, especially for newer devices that don't have a headphone jack. I also appreciate the built-in 3-button remote and mic—it makes it easy to take calls or adjust the volume without reaching for my phone. The EQ presets are a nice bonus for tweaking the sound to your liking.Overall, a great value for everyday listening, work calls, or travel.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Great Sounding JBL wired headphones
review_text: When I saw these JBL's, I just had to try them out. I like the quality of their speakers.These wired JBL headsets did not let me down.The sound quality was great. At half volume these JBL's are louder than my other headphones are at full volume.At full volume, which is very loud the JBL's still have great sounding music coming out.The connection is a USB-C so there is no time lag with the music. it also has a switch on the cord that has three buttons up, down volume and one for a preset EQ.It is also equipped with a microphone.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
About what you'd expect from JBL, really great baseline product.
review_text: Grabbed these up for yardwork and casual listening, and they’ve been awesome. Sound quality is super clear like you would expect from a JBL product. You get that nice thump without drowning out the mids and highs, which is exactly what I want in a pair of headphones.For on-ear style, the comfort’s actually better than I expected. Usually, these things start mashing and pinching my ears after a bit, but I’ve worn these for a few hours at a time with no problem. Soft pads, lightweight build, just a good fit.Bonus points for the inline controls sticking to the industry standard format instead of doing something "new and improved." Volume, play/pause, skip, mic...everything’s right where it should be, and it actually works without fumbling.All around, these are a great set of wired headphones for a great price. Solid pick for a baseline set of headphones with good sound and smart features.

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Sound is better than the price indicates
review_text: These sound very, very good for what are essentially budget headphones. The USB-C DAC used in these is clean sounding and the drivers delivery clarity and some low-end slam. I didn't expect such a mature sound from these plastic low-cost headphones.The build and fit, however, leave a little to be desired. I don't mind the on-ear design, but the way this headband is shaped (circular instead of slightly oval/oblong) means the sides of the headphones stand out quite a bit from the sides of your head. This looks kind of goofy, and some manufacturers have started moving away from this design.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
On ear USB C headphones that don't let down!
review_text: JBL is a trusted name in audio and they didn't let down with this set of on-ear headphones. They are comfortable with the padded ear donuts that are satin-like and soft, with a bit of firmness yet still conform to the contours of the ear. The cord is long enough to have your phone or plug in a backpack, pocket, or on your person and still have slack. The included in-line microphone and controls work well, and can be used for calls if needed. The sound has a great range! With some of my guitar rock, hip hop, edm playlists they produced great low bass and clean high end for clarity in audio. On audiobooks, and phone calls...the spoken word is clear and sounds full like someone actually talking in your ear. They are lightweight and feel well made, and the JBL brand is notable and lives up to the name. Great product for wired headphones with USB C connectivity.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars

review_text: Love the fit and light enough that it doesn't weight your head down.  Perfect for a little privacy for when you want to tune out and relax.  Would recommend this product as it is one of the better ones on the market.  100% satisfied.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Great for bass lovers
review_text: I always appreciate the fidelity of decent wired headphones over those with Bluetooth connections. These didn't disappoint, with a few qualifications.I compared them to a few other major brand on-ear wired headphones and these definitely had the best bass response and a good clean sound.Bass was strong and clean, definitely the main feature of these headphones, and a great reason to get them if you like powerful bass. But in all three EQ settings I found the mids and treble to be a bit weak compared to the other headphones I compared these to. Although weak in my opinion, the sound across all frequency ranges was very clean... much better than lower quality headphones.The microphone placement on the control module allows for good clean voice pickup (better than microphones located on headphone cups or earbuds). It does a good job masking the sound of the cable rubbing on your shirt (which some others don't).They don't come with any documentation, so here are a few tips. To toggle the EQ among bass-favoring, voice-favoring, or default, you need to hold down the volume ( + and - ) buttons simultaneously for 2 seconds. The setting will be announced as it switches. Tap the center button to pause/play, hold it briefly to activate voice commands (like Siri).These headphones fold flat for storage and the headband is adjustable, but they lack horizontal pivots on the earcups, so depending on your head shape they may press harder on the bottoms or tops of your ears. I didn't find this to be a big deal and they were comfortable enough on my big head.Overall, these are great sounding for the price, and if you're a bass lover you'll really enjoy them.

review_text: If you are looking for audio on a budget these little guys are hard to pass on. The Flats nearest competitor are the classic Koss Porta Pros. Both provide fantastic sound at great prices, but differ in two big ways. Firstly the JVCs cost 1/3 to 1/4 of a pair of Pros(which honestly makes them so hard to pass on) and secondly the sound. The Flats really live up to their name and have a great flat tone across genres vs the Pros. If you don't want to shell out the extra 20-30 for a warmer tone buy them and regret nothing. As a side note on durability you could probably break a pair of Porta Pros with a pair of Flats. I know that's not saying a heck of a lot(Porta Pros are held together by 2 plastic nubs and dreams), but you can expect them to survive a bag or a tumble without burning 30-40 for a new set

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Shouldn't sound or feel this good for $13 ( PortaPro alternative )
review_text: I bought these along with the somewhat coveted JLabs Rewind ( gen 2 ) Bluetooth headphones. I bought both because I've been looking for something that won't cause me physical ear fatigue or hurt immediately upon wearing.I REALLY wanted to love the JLabs because they offer something that the JVC Flats cannot.... No wires.  I LOATHE wires.That said. I will take the cables on these JVC Flats ANY day of the week because of what they offer over the JLabs Rewind.  Before I state what that is exactly, let me just say that the JLabs are about as comfortable as the JVC Flats.  Maybe more... But not quite,  without modifications.  I'll explain, because it's relevant.I have small ears.  And small ear canals. This is why I can't wear in-ear buds for too long, and is also why certain headphones hurt my ears or skull, depending upon how where and how they sit on my head and ears. It's a freaking curse.I started looking for headphones where one of the main selling points is being lightweight and comfortable.  Both these JVC'S and JLabs seemed to fit the bill when looking at their descriptions and reviews.  So, I bought both.I went into buying the JVC Flats knowing there was no mic or volume control, which I am actually fine with.  So I won't ding ding a star for it.What I wasn't expecting from the JVC Flats though.... Was how freaking good the sound quality would be! I have had several pairs of JVC marshmallow in ears, and now that I think about it, those sounded great, and are like fifteen bucks, so... Maybe I shouldn't be surprised?I should not that I also primarily wanted these for podcasts.  But when I heard the JVC Flats, I put on some music and was kind of floored.They instantly reminded me of Koss PortaPros, but with a tad more forward low and mid bass, maybe?  I used the PortaPros A LOT in my 20s and 30s and am now 53, so I've lost frequency range throughout the years.And they're LOUD! I don't need them to be this loud, but this is a terrible issue with the JLabs Rewind.  They're incredibly low.  Maybe lower voltage to increase battery life, but it's horrible.I'd have to put the volume to about 85% on the JLabs for basic, comfortable listening levels, whereas with these JVC'S, it's about 40% or less.  Fantastic.  And again, loud means nothing if it's loud and garbage.  These are loud and clear with no real bass mushiness even at uncomfortably loud levels.  Crystal clear.  Awesome.They fit snug on my ears, and the ear pads are cushy and fairly soft.  The outer layer is that faux leather material that always seems to eventually tear on headphones, so we'll see on that one....My only wish is that the actual driver housing was a TAD wider because while the driver seems to be positioned perfectly against my ear canal, the housing edges kind of hit the edges of my ear, causing some minor discomfort.Someone with normal, non-freakishly small ears, (which is most people), won't be bothered by this I guess.  What else. The head band, even though it has no padding, is barely noticeable.  Likely due to how light the frame is.  The band adjustment gives you a really pleasing tactile single groove click when adjusting.  Nice touch.I might give the JLabs a slight win in comfort, but ONLY if changing the foam pads on them, to something more foamy/cushy and soft.  As they are, the JLabs driver housing is very rigid and  my ears really feel that.  If I kept them, I'd modify them with some extra foam.  Otherwise, they're lighter than the JVC 's with a smaller earpiece frame.I might actually try to modify these JVC ear ups to make them wider.  I'll likely also buy a few spare sets because this pair is a gem.Great job JVC.If there's one negative thing I can say about them, it's that they're not being made with USB-C instead of just the 3.5mm input plug.  I hate having to use dongles.  I already had one, but I hate cables as it is, so....Anyway, if you're cool with cables, don't have freak ears, and want something super comfortable and want very good sound quality at a STEAL of a price...( Get a few now before the tariffs double their price), GET THESE!P.S.PortaPros are more detailed and have better soundstage.  But for $13 bucks, these are the ONES to beat.

review_text: I bought these for my late mother in 2017 to listen to music and help with TV. A perfect low cost choice. I took them out of storage to provide TV audio while my spouse sleeps. And they still work. As hoped. These are not the right choice for adult critical music listening sessions. But they do offer surprisingly satifying sound during long sessions like binge watching or podcast listening. They're lightweight so I barely notice them on ears or bald head. When music appears in a soundtrack or guest appearance, they often impress me with how restrained but noticeable the bass is-- again these are not appropriate for critical listening-- but great for the purposes I'm using this for. I've just added this to my list because sooner or later these will give out. But I figured while I'm in Amazon, I owed others the benefit of my experience. Only four stars because only audiophile equipmemt deserves that treatment. But I award five stars for value.

It does the job!
review_text: I owned a pair of these in 2013 and loved the quality. Buying another pair 11 years later and nothing has changed. Alot of headphones are heavy and super immersive which makes listening annoying after awhile. With these, they're so comfortable, lightweight, and flat with the sound in a good way that you can wear them enjoyably all day during a gaming session like I just did. The sound won't blow you out of the water but the vocals always come out clear and with the price point, I swear the quality is unmatched! Good job JVC!

review_title:
4.0 out of 5 stars
Incredibly Underrated Cans
review_text: If you are looking for one of the best kept secrets in headphones for both audiophiles and general listeners? Here she is, the Flats. Been around for many years, this has been a staple for me in my headphone journey. I’ve used a couple pairs on/off from 2012-as I write.With that said, the Flats aren’t for all. Let’s get that out of way! Big bass lovers, you look elsewhere. Need really great isolation, nah you can hear babies crying with these. Want a modern, sleek look? These have been around long enough to be retro now and kind of look it!That said, the sound and comfort are punching well above the price and looks would suggest. These cans provide a sound I would describe as: well balanced, mostly smooth but some sparkle in the treble. Clarity is slightly above average thanks to air and the treble crispness. Mid range feels a tad recessed but timbre is natural. Out of box they might sound somewhat metallic, let them play for several hours. That should go away. Bass, good punch, mostly a mid bass type of sound. Somewhat thick sounds but not rumbly or dark. A subtle V shape sounding headphone, which pleases most listeners.The comfort is top shelf. Due to their minimal design and weight, all cheap does help some things; I  can wear these hours and no fatigue. Cushions on the ear are just decent but keeps a loose seal to keep sound rich. But they rest on ear and are about the size of an average ear. So you should feel comfy and ears not too hot!At 12$, you are getting a killer value in headphones. Simple, basically timeless sound and design, and easy on the wallet?! It’s an easy recommendation! Remember, it’s not for those wanting Dre bass. It’s a balanced and clean set of cans. It will suit most genres other than those demanding pumping bass. Rock, metal, pop, mainstream, country; they all sound so crisp. Pick the color you like, and enjoy. The Royale blue color, it really pops in person.

I like wearing external phones so I can move them either onto or farther off of my ears to regulate volume and adjust for need to hear traffic. Considering all the use and abuse these phones have been through, I give them an A+ rating.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Wonderful
review_text: The **PHILIPS H4205 Wireless Headphones** have truly set a new standard for **sound quality**, **comfort**, and **design** in the realm of wireless on-ear headphones. With their sleek, modern aesthetic and **BASS Boost** feature, these headphones have become my **go-to choice** for music, podcasts, movies, and gaming. Whether you're a music enthusiast, an audio professional, or someone who simply enjoys high-quality sound, these headphones will **transform** your listening experience.### **Unbelievable Sound Quality:**Let’s talk about the sound quality—**PHILIPS has absolutely nailed it** with the H4205. The audio is **crystal clear**, with a powerful yet balanced soundstage. From the deep, resonating lows to the crisp, sharp highs, every note, beat, and voice comes through with **exceptional clarity**. The **BASS Boost** feature is a standout, delivering a punchy, immersive low end that **elevates** every genre of music, whether you're listening to hip-hop, rock, or electronic dance music. The bass is **rich and deep**, but never overwhelming or distorted, providing the perfect balance of power and clarity. It's the type of bass that makes you feel like you’re sitting in the front row of a concert.The **mid-range** frequencies also shine, ensuring that vocals and instrumental details are rendered with precision. Even when listening to complex compositions or podcasts, every sound is **distinguished** beautifully, allowing you to experience the **full depth of the audio**. The overall sound experience is **dynamic** and **immersive**, providing an unparalleled listening experience for all your favorite audio content.### **Ultimate Comfort:**Comfort is key when it comes to wearing headphones for long periods, and the **PHILIPS H4205** excels in this department. The **on-ear design** fits snugly without causing any discomfort or pain, even after hours of use. The **ear cups** are **padded** with a soft, cushioned material that gently rests on your ears without feeling too tight or heavy. The lightweight build makes it feel like you’re wearing **nothing at all**, and you can easily wear them for extended sessions—whether you’re working, exercising, or commuting—without ever feeling fatigued.The **adjustable headband** ensures a custom fit for different head sizes, while the **swiveling ear cups** make these headphones incredibly **portable** and easy to store when not in use. Whether you’re lounging at home or on the go, the **comfort** and **ease of wear** are simply outstanding.### **Wireless Freedom:**One of the most impressive features of the **PHILIPS H4205** is the **seamless Bluetooth connectivity**. Pairing the headphones with your device is **quick and easy**, and the Bluetooth connection is **stable** with minimal dropouts, even in areas with heavy wireless interference. The wireless functionality allows for **unmatched freedom**, so you can move around without worrying about tangled wires or restrictive cables. Whether you’re exercising, cooking, or simply lounging, you can enjoy your music without any distractions or limitations.### **Long Battery Life:**If you're someone who uses headphones frequently, you’ll appreciate the **long battery life** of the PHILIPS H4205. The **up to 28 hours of playtime** means you won’t have to worry about charging them every night. Whether you're using them for a full day of work, a long commute, or an entire workout, the battery will easily last through the entire session. When it’s time to recharge, the process is quick and hassle-free, ensuring that your headphones are always ready for the next round of music or entertainment.### **Built-in Controls for Easy Management:**Another standout feature of the **PHILIPS H4205** is its **easy-to-use built-in controls**. The headphone’s buttons are intuitively placed on the ear cups, allowing you to adjust volume, skip tracks, and answer calls with ease—all without needing to take out your phone. This simple but convenient design lets you manage your audio experience on the fly, without interrupting your flow or workflow. It’s especially useful during workouts or commutes when you don’t want to be constantly reaching for your phone.### **Sleek, Modern Design:**Not only does the **PHILIPS H4205** deliver on performance, but it also looks fantastic. The minimalist, sleek design is both **modern** and **stylish**, making these headphones a perfect accessory for any lifestyle. The smooth, matte finish and subtle branding give them a **premium** feel, while the foldable design makes them easy to carry and store when not in use. The clean lines and high-quality materials make these headphones look as good as they sound.### **Call Quality:**Another impressive feature of the **PHILIPS H4205** is its **call quality**. The built-in microphone ensures that your voice comes through **clear and sharp** during calls, even in noisy environments. The **noise-canceling capabilities** help eliminate background distractions, allowing for a more focused conversation. Whether you're on a conference call or chatting with friends, the sound quality of both your voice and the call will be exceptional.### **Conclusion:**The **PHILIPS H4205 Wireless Headphones** are, without question, a game-changer. The **sound quality**, **comfort**, **battery life**, and **stylish design** make them a perfect choice for anyone seeking a premium audio experience. Whether you’re using them for music, gaming, podcasts, or calls, these headphones deliver **exceptional performance** across the board. With the added bonus of **BASS Boost** for a deeper, more immersive sound experience, the H4205 takes your audio journey to a whole new level.If you’re looking for headphones that offer **unmatched sound quality**, **all-day comfort**, and **seamless wireless performance**, look no further. The **PHILIPS H4205** are, without a doubt, among the best on the market. **Highly recommended** for anyone serious about audio, style, and comfort.

review_title:
1.0 out of 5 stars
The savings aren't worth it
review_text: While I've been a loyal customer to Philips for a long time and usually satisfied, this time they've let me down. Sound quality is a steep downgrade from comparably priced headsets to such a degree that they fall into a lower tier entirely. Connectivity is unreliable and often requires multiple disconnects and reconnects just to work properly. Headphones will say "device connected" without actually being so. Worst of the lot though is the battery life. With a prior, similarly-priced headset I was able to go up to a week on a charge while this one can't get through the day. The battery life is only functionally 75% of the listed capacity, as every 90 seconds the headphones will interrupt your audio to repeat a "BATTERY LOW" voice warning. There is no way to turn this off and it will interrupt a single song two to three times, while the meter will show you having up to a quarter of your battery life left. The device can still be in the green on a battery meter and still will not function without being charged, in the most infuriating way imaginable. Budgeting in an extra $20 and going for a different brand will pay off to spare the frustration alone.

review_title:
2.0 out of 5 stars
Another example of a company ruining a product with absurd automatic functions
review_text: I bought these to replace a pair of BT510 that broke in my carry-on during a flight a few weeks ago. These were in sale, so figured I'd try the better model. I can't stand them. I think they sound a little worse than the cheaper 210s, but this is another product completely ruined by trying to decide for you what you want to do, and doing it, whether it's okay with you or not. They have some absurd feature where they automatically send a mute / pause command to any connected device if you so much as slightly light one side off your ear. Well first off that's just annoying in the first place, but even if I was into that kind of thing, they're so over-sensitive, that I've been using them for about a full week now, and not a single day has gone by that they havent shut off my music from me taking a sip of a drink, talking, or even just sitting absolutely still. SO frustrating. I'm going to buy another set of 210s because no way these are working on a flight with my head touching a headrest. To make matters worse, the first time I paired them to my phone, the driver asked permissions to link to my Google account?!?!? WHY?!?! I said no, and it did it anyway. Ita none of Googles business what headphones I'm wearing, and my email address and phone info darn sure isnt any of JBLs business. Only giving them 2 stars because the sound quality is half way decent when they dont stop your music. Oh, and the icing on the cake is the mute button functions as a hang up button on Teams, so yah, these hung up on a work conference call because I moved my mouth, and they sensed movement on my head and decided that means I want to hang up. Don't recommend these for any use, because they do what they want, and providing bare minimum basic function a set of speakers attached to your ears, is not one of those things! They're also extremely uncomfortable on my head compared to the 510s that are less than half the price.

review_title:
5.0 out of 5 stars
Great sound, great battery life, and the noise canceling works great!
review_text: I am really satisfied with the *JBL Live 460NC*. First of all, the *sound quality* puts it at the top of my list of headphones I have ever bought. The music is clear, the bass is solid, and the vocals are well defined. You hear every detail.The noise canceling (*Noise Canceling*) surprised me — it blocks out outside noise without cutting off the music. It is perfect for use on public transportation or while working. You feel isolated, but still comfortable.*The battery is the star!* It lasts *over 40 hours* without needing to be charged. I have used it for days without a problem. And if you need it, it has *quick charge*: just 10 minutes of charging gives you 4 hours of music!The headphones are lightweight, don't press on your ears, and are comfortable to wear for long periods of time. The buttons are easy to use, and the Bluetooth connection is stable. The JBL app also allows you to adjust the sound to your liking.In short, if you want a quality headphone, with good battery life, excellent sound, and noise cancellation, the *JBL Live 460NC* is a good investment!

review_title:
3.0 out of 5 stars
if you are a avid music listener i wouldnt suggest
review_text: So at first I really thought these headphones were great. I didn’t know it had a siri function but apparently it does and i low key think thats so useless maybe cause i dont use siri. But anyways, the buttons are pretty cool theres a weird switch on button to power it but it turns on within like a second. Im glad about that cause I hate it when it takes 5 years to turn on like the other 30$ jbl headphones. Also the sound is pretty good and its really noise canceling that was also a shock factor, I could barely hear people talking. Now onto its faults, Maybe because they are new headphones and you kinda have to break into them but they were tight on my ears/head like crazy. I got two massive headaches from it and i like to listen to music alot and for prolonged periods of time. Yeah its definetly not meant to be worn for a long time. Your ears get super sore too. Also a really annoying thing I hate is the fact that when you put them on a little tune plays and when you take them off a tune plays again and it shuts off your music. Got to be thee most unecesary feature jesus christ. Ill literally adjust the headphone on my head while listening to something and it will pause and for gods sake that tune does not have to play all the damn time! Sometimes ill wear it half off and it will pause the video and play THAT TUNE OMG. Okay let me calm down, other than the useless siri function, the tightness of the headphones ,and the automatic pause feature, id say they are okay. Ive had better headphones like i shouldve just stuck to sony but they legit wont connect to anything. Thats also a pro about these headphones, they connect to literally anything. It took me 3 months to get my sony headphones to connect to my laptop and i had to do that through charging it from my laptop. And I still never managed to connect it to my Ipad. These headphones managed to do that all within an instant like i didnt have to wait five years, they also connected to my schools laptops which again my sony COULD NOT DO!!! ugh

Great Quality, But Durability Could Be Better
review_text: Great Quality, But Durability Could Be BetterI bought these headphones for my 11-year-old to use with his school laptop, and overall, I was really happy with the purchase. They fit well, were comfortable to wear for long periods, and had good sound quality—perfect for schoolwork and occasional use at home.Unfortunately, they only lasted about half the school year. To be fair, my now 11-year-old can be pretty rough with his stuff. He didn’t use a case and often just tossed them into his backpack with books and other items. So while the durability wasn’t ideal, I still feel like the overall quality was solid for the price.In fact, I ended up purchasing another pair from the same brand to replace them. If your child is a bit more careful with their things, these headphones are a great choice!

Smaller than you think
review_text: I've been using JLab's GO Air Sport for years now and love them, but the in-ear buds get really uncomfortable for me during extended wear, so I'm looking for an alternative when I'm not active enough I have to use the earbuds, but these are just total garbage :(I saw several reviews that mentioned how small they are, but didn't think much of it because I *have* small ears for an adult, but these are so small the pads barely even *cover* my ears, much less go around them like this style of headphone is generally supposed to do. I only wore them for a few minutes and they were already getting uncomfortable.I've had cheaper headphones that sounded better, and were more comfortable than these, which is too bad.For pros? They're cheap and they did pair really easily, so I mean, if you're looking for cheap headphones (maybe for a child, because of the size) they'd probably be fine.I do also really like the physical buttons on the headphones themselves, most brands don't bother with those anymore. It's really too bad they're so uncomfortable/low sound quality :(

review_text: Hard to beat for the price and intended purpose. Nice overall sound with solid bass, good mids and highs---quite pleasant from a lower power source--I used a Surfans F20 as the sound source.  This is a an impressively well built set of phones with solid adjustment from the u-shaped can adjusters---they stick out a bit but that is the way the are built---fit good on smaller heads.  Unfortunately, they aren't great amplified. However, if you have an inexpensive MP3 player, these might be shockingly good at that level.  Strongly recommended for the low power user. I will return as I intend to run an external amp.

Great Sound and Noise Cancelling, but Fit and Portability Need Improvement
review_text: I purchased the JLab Lux ANC wireless headphones and have been impressed with the sound quality and the level of active noise cancelling.That said, there are two key issues that prevent this from being a 5-star product. First, the fit: the headphones are not snug enough and tend to slip off my head, even though I consider my head size to be average. This makes wearing them  with any kind of movement difficult.Second, the lack of a carrying case is a drawback. For a product at this price point, I would expect a travel case to protect the headphones, especially when tossing them into a backpack.If JLab addresses these two issues, improved fit and the inclusion of a case, I’d gladly upgrade this to a 5-star review.
